study_identification.title: Developmental trajectories of neuroanatomical alterations associated with the 16p11.2 Copy Number Variations

study_characteristics.study_objective: Characterize age-related effects of 16p11.2 CNVs on brain anatomy across a broad pediatric-to-young-adult age range using a normative developmental dataset for age/sex adjustment, and test whether alterations change with age.

dataset_name.Reason: NIHPD is used as the normative reference dataset; the 16p11.2 cohort comprises European (EU) and Simons VIP (SVIP) sites.
dataset_name.Supporting Text: As normative reference data for brain growth, we used the ... NIHPD project... Cross-sectional data was acquired in 2 different cohorts (the European -EU ... and the Simons VIP -SVIP).

hc_n.Reason: NIHPD normative model built on 339 children with 874 scans; the study sample includes 105 control individuals for comparison and normalization checks.
hc_n.Supporting Text: The normative model ... used data from 339 children ... for a total of 874 scans. ... This included ... 105 controls (CTRL).

hc_age.Answer: NIHPD: mean 11.0 years at first scan; enrollment 4.5–18.5 years. 16p11.2 CTRL: mean 14.15 (SD 4.24); range 4.67–22.92 years
hc_age.Reason: Age statistics reported for NIHPD baseline and for 16p11.2 control group in Table 1.
hc_age.Supporting Text: ... mean age at first scan of 11.0 years, ... Objective 1 (i.e. initial time-point for enrolment from 4.5 to 18.5 years) ... Table 1 ... CTRL Mean (SD) 14.15 (4.24); range 4.67-22.92.

hc_sex.Reason: NIHPD female/male counts are given; 16p11.2 control M/F counts are listed in Table 1; percentages computed from counts.
hc_sex.Supporting Text: The normative model ... used data from 339 children (179 females and 160 males)... Table 1 ... Sex (M/F) CTRL 67/38

imaging_modality.Reason: MRI protocol for 16p11.2 dataset specifies T1-weighted anatomical images across sites.
imaging_modality.Supporting Text: The MRI data from the 16p11.2 individuals included T1-weighted (T1w) anatomical images ...

analysis_level.Reason: Global/ROI volumes (whole brain and subcortical ROIs) and voxel-wise tensor-based morphometry (TBM) analyses were performed.
analysis_level.Supporting Text: We normalized volumes of segmented brain regions as well as volumes of each voxel defined by tensor-based morphometry.

preprocessing_pipeline.Answer: Denoising; N3 bias correction; histogram matching to ICBM152; linear registration to ICBM152; BEaST brain extraction; ANIMAL nonlinear registration; TBM with 10 mm FWHM smoothing; neuromorphometric atlas labeling
preprocessing_pipeline.Reason: Image processing steps and key software/methods are described in detail in the Image processing section.
preprocessing_pipeline.Supporting Text: ... (1) denoising, (2) intensity inhomogeneity correction using N3 ... (3) intensity normalization by histogram matching to the ICBM152 template ... linear registration ... BEaST ... ANIMAL ... TBM ... 3D Gaussian filter FWHM 10 mm ... anatomically labeled using the neuromorphometric atlas.

quality_checking.Reason: Both datasets indicate QC: NIHPD included only subjects that passed QC; 16p11.2 scans underwent thorough visual QC for motion artifacts.
quality_checking.Supporting Text: Only subjects that passed quality control were included. ... We performed a thorough visual quality control check looking for evidence of motion artefacts.

quality_checking_detail.Answer: NIHPD: only QC-passed subjects included. 16p11.2: thorough visual QC for motion artifacts; no counts reported.
quality_checking_detail.Reason: QC methods are described but numbers/thresholds are not provided.
quality_checking_detail.Supporting Text: Only subjects that passed quality control were included. ... We performed a thorough visual quality control check looking for evidence of motion artefacts.

site_effect_handling.Reason: In the NIHPD normative modeling, scanner fixed effect was tested and not retained; in the 16p11.2 analyses, raw values were corrected for protocol (single vs multi echo). Prior multisite artifact assessment reported no confounding of key regions.
site_effect_handling.Supporting Text: During model selection, a fixed effect for individual scanner was tested but found to be not significant ... Raw values ... corrected for age and protocol (i.e. single echo vs multi echo scans) through a linear model ... none of the regions ... could be attributed to artefacts introduced by the multisite analyses (Martin-Brevet et al., 2018).

site_effect_handling_detail.Answer: Scanner fixed effect tested in NIHPD mixed-effects modeling and excluded due to non-significance (BIC). 16p11.2 analyses included protocol (single vs multi echo) as covariate; previous study confirmed multisite effects did not drive findings.
site_effect_handling_detail.Reason: Explicit description of scanner effect testing and protocol adjustment; citation of prior multisite artifact evaluation.
site_effect_handling_detail.Supporting Text: ... fixed effect for individual scanner was tested but found to be not significant ... Raw values ... corrected for ... protocol ... none of the regions ... attributed to artefacts introduced by the multisite analyses (Martin-Brevet et al., 2018).

model_origin.Reason: Normative growth model trained on NIHPD longitudinal controls is used to compute age/sex-adjusted Z-scores applied to the 16p11.2 dataset.
model_origin.Supporting Text: We ... developed a longitudinal image processing pipeline and Z-scoring method ... using the NIH MRI study of normal brain development (NIHPD) ... In the present study, we use similar methods to Z-score a cross-sectional 16p11.2 dataset ...

model_origin_detail.Answer: NIHPD mixed-effects normative trajectories (Aubert-Broche et al.) trained on 339 children (179F/160M) with 2–3 scans each (874 scans), modeling quadratic age and sex; used to derive mean and SD for Z-scoring of global and voxel-wise measures.
model_origin_detail.Reason: Details on NIHPD cohort size and the mixed-effects model are specified, including quadratic age and sex terms and random effects.
model_origin_detail.Supporting Text: The normative model ... used data from 339 children ... 874 scans ... individual profiles suggest modeling brain growth as a quadratic function ... Linear effect of sex ... mixed-effects model that best fits the normative data is: ...

modeling_method.Answer: Linear mixed-effects normative model (quadratic age, sex) with Z-scoring; voxel-wise TBM using log-Jacobian determinants; group effects via linear models with interactions tested (age*sex, age*group).
modeling_method.Reason: Model specification and analysis steps are explicitly described.
modeling_method.Supporting Text: The mixed-effects model that best fits the normative data is: ... Z-scores ... For analyses ... We used a linear model introducing genetic status as a covariate ... interaction terms were tested: age*sex and age*group.

software_tool.Reason: They state analyses were conducted in R with nlme for mixed-effects models.
software_tool.Supporting Text: All analyses were conducted using R 3.4.0 ... The mixed-effect models were built using the nlme package.

response_variable.Answer: Global volumes (total brain, gray matter, white matter, lateral ventricles); subcortical/ROI volumes (lobes, thalamus, putamen, caudate, globus pallidus); voxel-wise log-Jacobian determinants (TBM)
response_variable.Reason: Response variables for both ROI/global and voxel-wise analyses are specified.
response_variable.Supporting Text: Whole-brain, individual lobes, thalamus, putamen, caudate, globus pallidus and ventricular volumes were calculated ... TBM ... Jacobian determinant ... used as a surrogate of the local volume difference ...

predictor_variables.Reason: Normative modeling included linear and quadratic age terms and sex as fixed effects.
predictor_variables.Supporting Text: ... modeling brain growth as a quadratic function ... Linear effect of sex was also included in the fixed terms ...

predictor_effects.Answer: Fixed effects: age (linear, quadratic), sex; Random effects: subject-level intercept and slope for age
predictor_effects.Reason: The mixed-effects model equation specifies random intercept and random slope and fixed terms for age and sex.
predictor_effects.Supporting Text: Vol_i = β0 + γ0 + (β1 + γ1)(Age_i-13) + β2(Age_i-13)^2 + β3 Sex_i + ε_i ... β are fixed effects; γ are random effects.

nm_vldtn_handle_ns.Reason: Age nonlinearity and sex handled via mixed-effects; scanner fixed effect tested and excluded; application across field strength/sites with protocol adjustment; normalization verified by absence of residual age/sex effects in controls.
nm_vldtn_handle_ns.Supporting Text: ... quadratic effects of age ... Linear effect of sex ... During model selection, a fixed effect for individual scanner was tested but found to be not significant ... we show ... model ... is robust and applies to data acquired on a 3T after a linear adjustment ... normalization ... neither sex nor age terms are significantly different than 0.

nm_vldtn_same_domain_nonindep.Reason: Model fit within NIHPD is illustrated (Supplementary Figure 3) showing mixed-effects fit; this reflects non-independent validation within training domain.
nm_vldtn_same_domain_nonindep.Supporting Text: Supplementary Figure 3. Mixed Effects fit of Total Brain Volume for NIHPD controls.

nm_vldtn_same_domain_indep.Reason: No explicit hold-out or independent validation set within the NIHPD domain is described.

nm_vldtn_diff_domain.Reason: They apply NIHPD-trained normative model to 16p11.2 data acquired on 3T; show robustness after linear adjustment and demonstrate post-normalization absence of age/sex effects in controls (Supplementary Figure 4).
nm_vldtn_diff_domain.Supporting Text: ... the model ... is robust and applies to data acquired on a 3T after a linear adjustment. ... Normalization procedure on 16p11.2 controls ... neither sex nor age terms are significantly different than 0.

clinical_dataset.Answer: 16p11.2 CNV carriers from EU consortium and Simons VIP (SVIP)
clinical_dataset.Reason: The clinical groups consist of deletion and duplication carriers recruited via EU and SVIP cohorts.
clinical_dataset.Supporting Text: Cross-sectional data was acquired in 2 different cohorts (the European -EU 16p11.2 consortium and the Simons VIP -SVIP study in North America).

diseases_studied.Answer: Neurodevelopmental risk associated with 16p11.2 CNVs (elevated ASD and related NDD risk)
diseases_studied.Reason: The introduction states 16p11.2 CNVs confer high risk for neurodevelopmental disorders including ASD.
diseases_studied.Supporting Text: 16p11.2 copy number variants ... confer high risk for neurodevelopmental disorders and are associated with structural brain alterations of large effect-size ... increased risk of developing autism spectrum disorders (ASD).

clinical_groups_n.Reason: Group sizes are reported in the cohort description and Table 1.
clinical_groups_n.Supporting Text: This included 56 ... deletion carriers ... 19 duplication carriers ... and 105 controls (CTRL). ... Table 1 N: DEL 56, CTRL 105, DUP 19

clinical_groups_age.Reason: Age statistics by group are reported in Table 1.

clinical_groups_sex.Answer: DEL: M/F 29/27; DUP: M/F 13/6; CTRL: M/F 67/38
clinical_groups_sex.Reason: Sex breakdown is listed in Table 1.

deviation_metric.Answer: Z-scores of global volumes and voxel-wise log-Jacobian determinants relative to NIHPD normative trajectories
deviation_metric.Reason: They compute Z-scores using NIHPD-derived mean and SD for both global and voxel-wise measures.
deviation_metric.Supporting Text: Using the mean and the estimated standard deviation of the model we were able to compute Z-scores ... for the global volumes ... as well as for each voxel independently ...

clinical_application_and_analysis.association_analysis: Linear models tested genetic status effects on normalized Z-scores with interactions (age*sex, age*group). Global volumes: Bonferroni correction for 8 comparisons; Voxel-wise TBM: FDR (q<0.05). No age interactions observed; stable differences across 4.5–23 years.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_brief: Inverse gene dosage effects in global and regional brain measures for 16p11.2 CNV carriers are present by ~4.5 years and remain stable through early adulthood.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_detailed: Deletion carriers showed higher Z-scores vs controls for total brain (mean Z=1.165, p<0.0001), gray (Z=0.414, p=0.00433) and white matter (Z=0.693, p<0.0001), whereas duplication carriers showed lower Z-scores (total brain Z=-1.17, p=0.0001; gray Z=-0.631, p=0.00272; white Z=-0.53, p=0.0018) and larger lateral ventricles (Z=1.629, p<0.0001). TBM revealed DEL>CTRL>DUP in bilateral calcarine cortex and insula, among others. No age*group interactions; effects stable across 4.5–23 years.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_limitations: Acquisition differences between normative (1.5T) and study (3T) data and multicenter variability may affect registrations; limited power for detecting small age-related changes (especially in DUP) and uncertainty at lower age range; generalizability may be limited for extreme obesity or severe ASD unable to complete scanning.
clinical_application_and_analysis.application_notes: Normalization approach enables cross-age analysis using external normative trajectories; authors suggest future refinements with 3T longitudinal data and alternative modeling (e.g., splines) to better capture variability.

general_notes.general_notes: NIHPD ancestry composition similar to 16p11.2 cohort; analyses conducted in R 3.4.0 (nlme); labeling via neuromorphometric atlas; prior multisite artifact checks cited (Martin-Brevet 2018).
